Award.AwardTitle: WIDER:Planning: GRASP: GW Reform and Advancement of STEM-education Practices

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
This WIDER planning project is addressing the challenges of student learning, diversity, and retention in STEM by promoting evidenced-based pedagogies with proven organizational change frameworks. The project is being implemented by a team of faculty with a depth and breadth of accumulated expertise in transforming faculty educational practices. The team is working work with colleagues in ten STEM departments to develop a framework in which to pilot the use of four effective pedagogies, as a prelude to a larger implementation phase. The four pedagogies are: (1) Peer-instruction; (2) SCALE-UP; (3) Blended learning and flipped classrooms; and (4) Online customized tutoring in mathematics to accompany mathematics and statistics coursework. To achieve the transformation, the project will focus on core faculty beliefs about student learning as a means for identifying opportunities for transformation. The project will also rely both on proven transformative processes at GW, such as faculty learning communities, as well as organizational change approaches recommended in the education community, such as the Concerns Based Adoption Model (CBAM). The project will forge the collaborations among faculty needed to adopt future developments in STEM pedagogy, and to form an agent of transformative change on campus.

This project will also seek to understand the core issues in recruiting and retaining students from non-dominant and underrepresented groups, as well as impact student learning in non-major STEM courses through the use of evidence-based pedagogies. The change processes and materials developed in this project can serve as a model at other universities.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The project supported planning and pilot implementation of approaches aimed at improving student learning in STEM courses, particularly at the early undergraduate level and using evidence-based pedagogical approaches. Student learning in STEM courses is impacted by various factors. Studies have shown that learning is improved when evidence-based approaches are used, such as active learning, peer-instruction, supplemental online learning and problem-based learning. In general, carefully designed learning activities that are hands-on in class improve student engagement and motivation, and eventually lead to improved learning.

 

The outcomes of this particular project have included the development of several evidence-based approaches in undergraduate STEM courses at the institution. These include: (1) the development and application of active learning modules in mathematics literacy; (2) the development of active learning modules in biomedical engineering and civil engineering coursework; (3) the application of novel pedagogical frameworks in introductory astrophysics and in biology; (4) enhancing math skills for increased success in introductory economics; (5) the development of tools to improve access to introductory computer science courses; (6) the use of problem-based learning in an engineering management course. As an example, consider the fact that many students coming into introductory economics are surprised to discover that the study of economics requires facility with high-school mathematics. Instead of letting such students continually struggle and fall farther behind, the approach developed here provides supplemental training in mathematics that is embedded in the economics examples that motivate students to practice their math skills while remaining in the course. The data about student performance shows that the approach results in increased student performance.
